4.3. Here are two versions of the circle function.
def circle(radius):
    circumference = 2  math.pi  radius
    n = 30
    length = circumference / n
    polygon(n, length)

def circle(radius):
    arc(radius,  360)

What can we say about these functions?

column3: a) They have the same implementation, but different interfaces.
b) They have the same interface and the same implementation.
c) They have neither the same interface nor the same implementation.
d) They have the same interface, but different implementations.

MC: They take the same parameter and have the same effect, so they have the same interface -- but they accomplish the effect in different ways, so they have different implementations.
MC

b) a is 2 and b is 250
c) a is 2.5 and b is 250
d) a is 2 and b is 5

MC: The // operator does integer division and the % operator computes the remainder after division.

d) 'x is an int, 1. t is a tuple, (1,)'

b) 'stop'

14.1. To create an instance of a programmer-defined type, what is the correct order for these steps?

column3: a) Assign values to attributes, define a class, instantiate an object.
b) Instantiate an object, define a class, assign values to attributes.
c) Define a class, assign values to attributes, instantiate an object.
d) Define a class, instantiate an object, assign values to attributes.

MC: You have to define a class, instantiate an object, and assign values to attributes, in that order.
MC

14.2. These statements are intended to define a Date class and create a Date object. What is wrong with them?
def Date:
    """Represents a day of the year."""
    
date = Date()
date.year = 2024
date.month = 'January'
date.day = 11

column3: a) You can't have a class named Date and a variable named date.
b) All of the attributes have to have the same type.
c) The syntax is not correct for adding attributes to the object.
d) A class definition has to start with class, not def.

MC: A class definition has to start with class. A function definition starts with def.
MC

14.3. Which of these is a correct description of this function? You can assume that date is a Date object that has a day attribute.

def increment_day(date):
    date.day += 1
    return date

column3: a) It is a pure function that returns None.
b) It is an impure function that returns None.
c) It is a pure function that returns a Date object.
d) It is an impure function that returns a Date object.

MC: This function modifies an attribute of the Date object it gets as a parameter, so it is an impure function -- and it returns a reference to the same Date object.
MC

15.1. Suppose time is a Time object, and increment is an instance method defined in the Time class. What happens when we invoke increment like this?

time.increment(42)

column3: a) 42 is assigned to the first parameter of the method, and time is assigned to the second.
b) This is an error because increment requires one arguments and two are provided.
c) This is an error because increment requires two argument and only one is provided.
d) time is assigned to the first parameter of the method and 42 is assigned to the second.

MC: time is assigned to the first parameter of the method, which is conventionally called self, and 42 is assigned to the second.
MC

15.2. Suppose time is a Time object, and int_to_time is a static method defined in the Time class. What happens when we invoke int_to_time like this?

start = Time.int_to_time(34800)

column3: a) This is an error because int_to_time requires one argument and two are provided.
b) The Time class object is assigned to the first parameter of the method and 34800 is assigned to the second.
c) 34800 is assigned to the first parameter of the method and the Time class object is assigned to the second.
d) 34800 is assigned to the first parameter of int_to_time.

MC: 34800 is assigned to the first parameter of int_to_time. Because Time is a class, it is not passed as an argument.
MC
15.3. Which of the following statements is NOT correct?

column3: a) When we instantiate an object, its __init__ method is invoked.
b) When we use the + operator with an object, its __add__ method is invoked.
c) When we print an object, its __str__ method is invoked.
d) When we define a new class, its __init__ method is invoked.

MC: Defining a new class does not invoke its __init__ method.
MC

column3: a) pure
b) equivalent
c) static
d) polymorphic

MC: A function that works with more than one type is polymorphic.
MC

column3: a) __init__ is not a legal name for a method because it does not start with a letter.
b) The triple-quoted string has to be inside a method definition.
c) The first parameter of the method should be called point, not self.
d) The assignment statements should be the other way around, as in self.x = x and self.y = y.

MC: The assignment statements should be the other way around, as in self.x = x and self.y = y.
MC

column3: a) The result is a deep copy that copies the Line object and the Point objects it contains.
b) The result is a deep copy that copies the Line object but not the Point objects it contains.
c) The result is a shallow copy that copies the Line object and the Point objects it contains.
d) The result is a shallow copy that copies the Line object but not the Point objects it contains.

MC: The copy function makes a shallow copy, which copies the Line object but not the Point objects it contains.
MC
17.1. Which of the following is NOT a correct statement about class variables.

column3: a) They are defined inside a class definition, but not inside a method definition.
b) They can be accessed using a class object.
c) They can have any type.
d) They are immutable.

MC: This statement is false -- that is, class variables are mutable.
MC

column3: a) Hand is a parent class and Deck is a child class.
b) Every function that works with Hand should also work with Deck.
c) Every Hand object has the same attributes as every Deck object, no more or less.
d) Every method defined in the Deck class can also be invoked on a Hand object.

17.4. What do we call it when one method invokes another to do most or all of the work?

column3: a) inheritance
b) generalization
c) specialization
d) delegation

MC: Delegation is when one method passes responsibility to another method to do most or all of the work.
MC

18.1. What is the result of this operation?
set('abba') <= set('abc')

column3: a) False because 'abba' is longer than 'abc'.
b) A runtime error because 'abba' contains duplicate elements, so it is not a set.
c) A runtime error because a string is immutable, so it cannot be transformed into a set.
d) True because the elements of 'abba' are a subset of the elements of 'abc'.

MC: With set objects, the <= operator checks whether one set is a subset of another -- including the possibility that they are equal.
MC

18.2. What is the value of counter after these statements run?
from collections import Counter

t = (1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 3)
counter = Counter(t)
The result is a Counter object that contains the elements of the list and the number of times each one appears.
MC

column3: a) All Game objects refer to different dictionaries.
b) All Game objects refer to the same dictionary.
c) All Game objects created with the default value of scores refer to an empty dictionary.
d) All Game objects created with the default value of scores refer to the same dictionary.

MC: All Game objects created with the default value get a reference to the same dictionary -- so if any of them modify it, they all see the change.
MC

18.4. What is the value of this expression?
all(number < 10 for number in [2, 4, 6, 8])

column3: a) [2, 4, 6, 8], which contains all numbers in the list less than 10.
b) An error because the list comprehension has to be in square brackets.
c) False because there are not any numbers in the list that are not less than 10.
d) True because all numbers in the list are less than 10.

MC: The values produced by the generator expression are all True, so the result from the all function is True.
MC

18.5. What is the value of d[key] after these statements run, or is there an error?
from collections import defaultdict

d = defaultdict(list)
key = ('into', 'the')
d[key].append('woods')

column3: a) An error because a tuple cannot be used as a key in a defaultdict.
b) An error because we have to add the key to the defaultdict before we can look it up.
c) 'woods'
d) ['woods']

MC: When the key is added to the defaultdict, the corresponding value is an empty list. After the append method is invoked, the list contains a single element, the string 'woods'.
MC

pack_and_print(a=1, b=2)

MC

S.5. What is wrong with the following program?

S.6. Which of these is a correct way to convert a string to lowercase?

b) str = lower(str)
c) str.lower()
d) str = str.lower()

MC: str.lower() creates a new string -- if we assign it back to str, the new string replaces the old one. See Chapter 7.
MC

column3: a) Returns the letters that appear in either word1 or word2 or both.
b) Returns the letters that appear in either word1 or word2 but not both.
c) Returns the letters that appear in word1 but not word2.

S.8. This function is intended to convert the first letter of a word to lowercase and the rest of the letters to uppercase.

def lower_upper(wor**d):
    first = word[0]
    rest = word[1:]
    word = first.lower() + rest.upper()

What is the value of word if we call this function like this -- or is there an error?
word = lower_upper('Python')

column3: a) The result is a syntax error because a : character cannot appear inside the bracket operator.
b) The result is a runtime error because 0 is not a valid index.
c) The program is correct -- the value of word is 'pYTHON'.
d) The program contains a logic error -- the value of word is None.

MC: The function has no return statement, so it returns None. Assigning a new value to the parameter word has no effect outside the function. See Chapter 9.
MC

t[1:-1]

a, b = 1, 2
a, b = b, a

S.12. Why can't a list appear as a key in a dictionary?

column3: a) The elements in a list might not be totally ordered.
b) The elements in a list can be different types.
c) Lists can contain any number of elements.
d) Lists are mutable, which makes them unhashable.

MC: If an object is mutable, it isn't hashable, which means it can't be used as a key in a dictionary. See Chapter 10, chaptertitle" and Chapter 11."
MC
S.13. What is the primary difference between a list and a tuple?

column3: a) A list can contain any type; a tuple can only contain hashable types.
b) A tuple can contain any type; a list can only contain hashable types.
c) A tuple is mutable; a list is immutable.
d) A list is mutable; a tuple is immutable.

MC: A tuple is immutable. See Chapter 11.
MC
S.14. Which of these is a correct way to reverse the elements of a list in place -- that is, by modifying an existing list without creating a new list?

column3: a) t = reversed(t)
b) reversed(t)
c) t = t.reverse()
d) t.reverse()

MC: t.reverse() reverses the elements of t without creating a new list. See Chapter 11.
MC

S.15. What is the result of this program?
s = ['bbb', 'aa', 'c']
sorted(s, key=len, reverse=True)
key=len sorts by length, rather than alphabetical order, and reverse=True sorts in descending order, so the result is ['bbb', 'aa', 'c']. See Chapter 12.
MC

b) Adds the keys from d2 to d1.
c) Makes a new dictionary with all keys that are in both d1 and d2.
d) Makes a new dictionary with all keys that are in either d1 or d2.

MC: The new dictionary has all keys from either dictionary. If the same key appears in both, it gets the value from d2. See Chapter 12.
MC

S.17. Suppose we run the following program to get the current working directory:
import os

os.getcwd()
And the result is /home/dinsdale/photos. Now suppose we run the following program to check for the existence of a file:
os.path.exists('apr-2023/photo1.jpg')
What is the absolute path of the file that gets checked?

column3: a) 'photo1.jpg'
b) 'apr-2023/photo1.jpg'
c) '/home/dinsdale/photo1.jpg'
d) '/home/dinsdale/photos/apr-2023/photo1.jpg'

MC: Because 'apr-2023/photo1.jpg' is a relative path, it gets joined to the current working directory. See Chapter 13.
MC

column3: a) f'Today is Wednesday'
b) 'Today is {Wednesday}'
c) f'Today is {date.day}'
d) 'Today is Wednesday'

MC: In a format string, the expression in curly braces gets replaced by its value. See Chapter 15.
MC

S.19. Assuming that the Animal class exists, what is the output of this program?
class Cat(Animal):
    """Represents a cat."""
 \n   
cat = Cat()
isinstance(cat, Animal)

column3: a) False because an instance of a parent class is not an instance of the child class.
b) False because an instance of a child class is not an instance of the parent class.
c) True because every instance of a parent class is also an instance of the child class.
d) True because every instance of a child class is also an instance of the parent class.

MC: In this example, Cat is a child class of Animal, so every Cat object is also an instance of Animal. See Chapter 17.
MC

S.20. What is the result of this program?
from collections import namedtuple
\n
Point = namedtuple('Point', ['x', 'y'])
p = Point(3, 4)
p[1]

column3: a) AttributeError because the attributes of p are x and y.
b) IndexError because the attributes of p are x and y.
c) because p is a namedtuple and the element with index 1 is 3.
d) 4 because p is a namedtuple and the element with index 1 is 4.

MC: In a named tuple -- as in a tuple -- the index of the second element is 1. See Chapter 18.
MC

S.21. We can call the built-in function round like this:
import math

round(math.pi, ndigits=3)
The result is the value of math.pi round off to three decimal places. 

Now suppose we have the positional argument in a tuple and the keyword argument in a dictionary, like this:
args = (math.pi,)
kwargs = {"ndigits": 3}

Which of these is a correct way to call round and get the same result?

column3: a) round(args, kwargs)
b) round(*args, kwargs)
c) round(**args, *kwargs)
d) round(*args, *kwargs)

MC: The operator unpacks the elements of args and the * operator unpacks the items in kwargs. See Chapter 18.
